instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
hello,

Flux traces in the <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> region
same 5v on all dc inputs


I removed the <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> and read 5 volts on pin 1 again.
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> = 5 volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
VDDA pin shows 100ohm with gnd. When I check the same pin on another board, 500ohm appears. Could the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> be faulty?

I replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. It draws 5v 0.029a right now

(<RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR>) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>= 3.4 volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all big coils.
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> goes high?

Test with known good battery (charged).
Also be sure to use 87W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> = 5.1 Volt
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.2 Volt
VDDA = 5Volt
VDDAp = 5 Volt
<SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR>) = 5 Volt
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL> = 3.4 Volt
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> (<TRANSISTOR>Q5490</TRANSISTOR> pin2) = 3.4 Volt
(D4)AMON <SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> = 3.4 Volt
BMON <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> = No Voltage

<RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> = No Voltage

big coils are not short circuited

diode mode  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.406

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> = 3.4 Volt"
Check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and their traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Soryy
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> = No Voltage <RESISTOR>R5439</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> = No Voltage <RESISTOR>R5429</RESISTOR>


No problem with <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 resistors  and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 = 5 volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
I told you to check these resistors based on your bad reading.
No need to check them in fact.
Please, post accurate information in the future...

One of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> may be bad, or SMC has internal damage.
Be sure first that <RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> is good.
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> must stay high.

"Test with known good battery (charged).
Also be sure to use 87W charger."
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
I checked again this morning and saw 20 volts instead of 5 volts on the keweısı. But the amperage drawn is 0 when I first plug it in, it draws 0.17a and then it drops to zero.

No original charger. I tried it with its own battery, it didn't charge. The charger I am using now creates all voltages on the same model motherboard.

<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>  = No voltage
<RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> good

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> : 19v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> : 3.4 Volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: 20v when I plug it into the j3300 side and 5 0.29a volts when I plug it into the jb500 side

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Then you have problems on <SIGNAL>USB_C</SIGNAL> area of JB500.
Compare diode mode readings on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> LDOs between both sides.
I also recommend to check on all JB500 lines.

BTW, get original set of 87-96-140W chargers for repair processes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
I checked the LDOs lines, no shorts
I checked all the parts near the ub300/400 with gnd there is no short circuit
How can I narrow the field?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Not only short is bad.
You must compare the readings with good channel.
Also check if all LDOs come on on that area.

Don't forget to make a backup first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings between J3300 and JB500 pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Does having these voltages mean that the ub300/400 is working or  isn't ? So even if I have these voltages, is there a possibility that it is still faulty?

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> / CB308 = 3,4 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> / = 1,7 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1,8 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 1,1 Volt

<SIGNAL>1PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3,4 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1,8 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1,8 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 1,1 Volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
You may have a problem on the data lines of JB500.
Even if UB300/400 are both good, can't work properly if some input is not good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
I tried with a full battery, it won't turn on.
I replaced UB300/400, same result.
When the battery is not plugged in, the jb500 side gets 5 volts. But when the battery is inserted, it turns to 19 volts. The device does not charge and does not turn on.
It's 19v when the battery is plugged in. When the battery is not plugged in, it is 5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
You must get same behavior on all USB-C ports.
You still have problems on USB-C areas, if can't switch to 20V without battery.
